## Conversation History:
Doctor: What brings you in today?
Patient: I'm a 26-year-old nurse and I've been having severe fatigue and weakness. I've been told my hemoglobin is very low at 7.5 g/dL.
Doctor: REQUEST TEST: Vital_Signs
Measurement: RESULTS: Blood pressure 90/60 mmHg, Heart rate 110 bpm, showing tachycardia and hypotension. Patient appears pale.
Doctor: Have you noticed any bleeding or blood in your stool?
Patient: No, I haven't noticed any bleeding. All my tests for bleeding have come back negative. I also have these crusts along the veins on my left arm.

## Retrieved Experiences (id, observation):
ID: 1 | Observation: Patient is a 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anaemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL) and marked reticulocytosis (13.3%) despite exhaustive negative workup for bleeding, hemolysis, marrow disease, GI and gynecologic sources, and normal iron/B12/epu. Physical exam shows crusts along veins on the left arm and pale appearance; vitals show tachycardia and hypotension. The patient expresses high cancer concern and requests invasive diagnostic laparoscopy.
ID: 4 | Observation: Physical findings include crusts along veins on left armlocal lesions consistent with repeated venipuncture, IV access, or self-inflicted injury. The patient is a nurse, increasing access to equipment and skills for intravenous manipulation. Despite hypotension and tachycardia, there is lack of corroborating signs of ongoing bleeding or hemolysis.
ID: 14 | Observation: Recurrent brief diarrheal episodes (a few days), migratory asymmetric joint pain focused on one arm, no objective inflammatory signsnormal WBC, CRP, ESR, normal stool studies, no joint swelling or warmth on exam or imaging, negative HLA-B27, and symptoms persisted across multiple ER visits without progressive structural findings.
ID: 16 | Observation: The agent relied on temporal association (diarrhea and joint pain starting together) without confirming typical reactive arthritis features: asymmetric lower-extremity oligoarthritis, enthesitis, conjunctivitis/urethritis, or antecedent known enteric infection; also patient denied classic extra-articular signs and had no response trial to NSAIDs.
ID: 2 | Observation: Lab pattern shows normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers (LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin), direct antiglobulin test, peripheral smear including specialized hematopathology review, flow cytometry for PNH, erythropoietin, and bone marrow biopsy are normal. Stool occult blood, EGD, abdominal CT, pelvic exam and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Repeated identical CBC results despite multiple draws raise concern for nonphysiologic causes.
ID: 17 | Observation: Limited therapeutic probing was donepatient never tried NSAIDs and there was no trial of symptom-directed therapy or functional assessments to distinguish inflammatory vs noninflammatory pain. Also, physical exam lacked tests for non-organic signs (e.g., Hoover sign, Waddell's signs) or functional pain reproduction.
ID: 9 | Observation: Management plan focused on reassurance and repeating serum hCG in one week without addressing the patient's belief in being pregnant, potential emotional impact of a nonpregnancy diagnosis, or arranging appropriate follow-up if negative tests persist.
ID: 10 | Observation: Pitting of the nails noted on exam and patient reports chronic dandruff (scalp scaling)  subtle cutaneous/nail findings that can be manifestations of psoriasis were present but not pursued.
ID: 15 | Observation: Symptoms lack focal/localizing features and often coincide with healthcare-seeking behavior: diffuse abdominal tenderness without peritoneal signs, arm tenderness nonlocalized, normal imaging/ultrasound/ labs across episodes, and the patient has multiple prior ER visits for similar complaints.
final_response:
{"status": "experiences_selected", "selected": [{"id": 1, "suggestion": "When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes."}, {"id": 4, "suggestion": "Perform a focused dermatologic and venous site exam: inspect for patterned scabs, linear tracks, healed puncture wounds, unexplained adhesive residues, or tubing marks. Document photographs (with consent) and compare bilateral arms. Ask explicit questions about IV access, self-injection of substances (including own blood), or use of sharps at home or work. Secure sharp instruments if immediate risk is identified. Rationale: visible puncture marks and crusting are direct physical clues of self-inflicted intravenous manipulation; documenting and addressing access can prevent further harm and provide objective evidence guiding psychiatric referral and safe management."}], "reasoning": "Both experiences directly match the patient's presentation of severe anemia, hypotension, tachycardia, and the presence of crusts along the veins. Experience 1 describes a similar patient with severe anemia and negative workup for bleeding, while experience 4 discusses the physical findings of crusts along the veins and the absence of ongoing bleeding despite hypotension and tachycardia.", "context_for_doctor": "[Experience #1]
Pattern: Patient is a 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anaemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL) and marked reticulocytosis (13.3%) despite exhaustive negative workup for bleeding, hemolysis, marrow disease, GI and gynecologic sources, and normal iron/B12/epu. Physical exam shows crusts along veins on the left arm and pale appearance; vitals show tachycardia and hypotension. The patient expresses high cancer concern and requests invasive diagnostic laparoscopy.
Suggestion: When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes.

[Experience #4]
Pattern: Physical findings include crusts along veins on left arm—local lesions consistent with repeated venipuncture, IV access, or self-inflicted injury. The patient is a nurse, increasing access to equipment and skills for intravenous manipulation. Despite hypotension and tachycardia, there is lack of corroborating signs of ongoing bleeding or hemolysis.
Suggestion: Perform a focused dermatologic and venous site exam: inspect for patterned scabs, linear tracks, healed puncture wounds, unexplained adhesive residues, or tubing marks. Document photographs (with consent) and compare bilateral arms. Ask explicit questions about IV access, self-injection of substances (including own blood), or use of sharps at home or work. Secure sharp instruments if immediate risk is identified. Rationale: visible puncture marks and crusting are direct physical clues of self-inflicted intravenous manipulation; documenting and addressing access can prevent further harm and provide objective evidence guiding psychiatric referral and safe management."}

Pattern: Recurrent brief diarrheal episodes (a few days), migratory asymmetric joint pain focused on one arm, no objective inflammatory signs—normal WBC, CRP, ESR, normal stool studies, no joint swelling or warmth on exam or imaging, negative HLA-B27, and symptoms persisted across multiple ER visits without progressive structural findings.
Suggestion: Before diagnosing reactive arthritis, seek objective evidence of inflammatory arthritis and infection. Specifically: (1) Carefully document and attempt to elicit objective synovitis (joint swelling, warmth, reduced passive ROM) and repeat exam during symptomatic flare; (2) consider bedside joint aspiration if true effusion suspected to demonstrate inflammatory fluid; (3) refrain from inferring post-infectious reactive arthritis when inflammatory markers, stool studies, joint imaging/ultrasound, and HLA-B27 are repeatedly negative. Rationale: Reactive arthritis is an inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy typically with objective synovitis, enthesitis, or extra-articular features; without objective evidence its probability is low and alternative (functional/somatization) causes become more likely.

Use validated brief screens (PHQ-9, GAD-7) and ask about symptom impact on work/relationships. If positive or if symptoms are inconsistent with objective findings, refer early to mental health or psychosomatic medicine and consider multidisciplinary care (physiotherapy, pain clinic, CBT). Rationale: Recurrent multisystem symptoms with normal tests raise somatization which responds to structured psychological interventions; early recognition reduces unnecessary testing and harms."}

Suggestion: When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes.

[Experience #2]
Pattern: Lab pattern shows normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers (LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin), direct antiglobulin test, peripheral smear including specialized hematopathology review, flow cytometry for PNH, erythropoietin, and bone marrow biopsy are normal. Stool occult blood, EGD, abdominal CT, pelvic exam and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Repeated identical CBC results despite multiple draws raise concern for nonphysiologic causes.
Suggestion: Recognize that a high reticulocyte count with absent biochemical/hematologic evidence of hemolysis and no identified bleeding source should prompt consideration of specimen contamination, specimen manipulation (exogenous transfusion, reinfusion), or factitious blood loss. Actions: request chain-of-custody for specimens, perform witnessed sample collection and immediate repeat testing (including point-of-care Hb) to exclude lab tampering; compare venous versus capillary/point-of-care samples. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics."}

Suggestion: Actively screen for somatoform/somatization and psychiatric comorbidity: ask about mood/anxiety symptoms, sleep, functional impairment, stressors, secondary gains, and prior mental health diagnoses or treatments. Use validated brief screens (PHQ-9, GAD-7) and ask about symptom impact on work/relationships. If positive or if symptoms are inconsistent with objective findings, refer early to mental health or psychosomatic medicine and consider multidisciplinary care (physiotherapy, pain clinic, CBT). Rationale: Recurrent multisystem symptoms with normal tests raise somatization which responds to structured psychological interventions; early recognition reduces unnecessary testing and harms.

[Experience #14]
Pattern: Recurrent brief diarrheal episodes (a few days), migratory asymmetric joint pain focused on one arm, no objective inflammatory signs—normal WBC, CRP, ESR, normal stool studies, no joint swelling or warmth on exam or imaging, negative HLA-B27, and symptoms persisted across multiple ER visits without progressive structural findings.
Suggestion: Before diagnosing reactive arthritis, seek objective evidence of inflammatory arthritis and infection. Specifically: (1) Carefully document and attempt to elicit objective synovitis (joint swelling, warmth, reduced passive ROM) and repeat exam during symptomatic flare; (2) consider bedside joint aspiration if true effusion suspected to demonstrate inflammatory fluid; (3) refrain from inferring post-infectious reactive arthritis when inflammatory markers, stool studies, joint imaging/ultrasound, and HLA-B27 are repeatedly negative. Rationale: Reactive arthritis is an inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy typically with objective synovitis, enthesitis, or extra-articular features; without objective evidence its probability is low and alternative (functional/somatization) causes become more likely."}

Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics."}], "reasoning": "ID 1 directly matches the current case: 26-year-old nurse with identical lab findings (Hb 7.5 g/dL, reticulocytosis 13.3%), physical findings (crusts along veins on left arm), vital signs (tachycardia and hypotension), and similar clinical context. Pattern: Patient is a 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anaemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL) and marked reticulocytosis (13.3%) despite exhaustive negative workup for bleeding, hemolysis, marrow disease, GI and gynecologic sources, and normal iron/B12/epu. Physical exam shows crusts along veins on the left arm and pale appearance; vitals show tachycardia and hypotension. The patient expresses high cancer concern and requests invasive diagnostic laparoscopy.
Suggestion: When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes.

[Experience #2]
Pattern: Lab pattern shows normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers (LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin), direct antiglobulin test, peripheral smear including specialized hematopathology review, flow cytometry for PNH, erythropoietin, and bone marrow biopsy are normal. Stool occult blood, EGD, abdominal CT, pelvic exam and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Repeated identical CBC results despite multiple draws raise concern for nonphysiologic causes.
Suggestion: Recognize that a high reticulocyte count with absent biochemical/hematologic evidence of hemolysis and no identified bleeding source should prompt consideration of specimen contamination, specimen manipulation (exogenous transfusion, reinfusion), or factitious blood loss. Actions: request chain-of-custody for specimens, perform witnessed sample collection and immediate repeat testing (including point-of-care Hb) to exclude lab tampering; compare venous versus capillary/point-of-care samples. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics."}

Why: Nail pitting and scalp scaling are common and sometimes sole clues to psoriatic arthritis; identifying skin/nail psoriasis would change pre-test probability and prompt consideration of psoriatic arthritis rather than OA.

Pattern: Presentation of asymmetric mono/oligoarticular knee involvement with prior brief episode in the contralateral knee, acute swelling with warmth and tenderness, and raised inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP) — pattern is more typical of inflammatory arthritis rather than purely mechanical OA.

Suggestion: Before diagnosing reactive arthritis, seek objective evidence of inflammatory arthritis and infection. Specifically: (1) Carefully document and attempt to elicit objective synovitis (joint swelling, warmth, reduced passive ROM) and repeat exam during symptomatic flare; (2) consider bedside joint aspiration if true effusion suspected to demonstrate inflammatory fluid; (3) refrain from inferring post-infectious reactive arthritis when inflammatory markers, stool studies, joint imaging/ultrasound, and HLA-B27 are repeatedly negative. Suggestion: When patients have persistent pregnancy symptoms and strong conviction of pregnancy but all objective pregnancy tests (urine and serial quantitative serum hCG) and TVUS are negative, include pseudocyesis on the differential. ACTIONS: 1) Explicitly ask about timing/number/brands of home tests, prior positive results, and verify any prior outside lab hCG results. 2) Re-confirm serial serum quantitative hCG and review lab reports to exclude lab error or heterophile antibodies. 3) If testing reliably negative, perform focused psychosocial and psychiatric screening (ask about intense desire to conceive, recent pregnancy loss or infertility, mood symptoms, body image changes, and any secondary gains). 4) Arrange early mental health referral and schedule close follow-up to reassess symptoms and objective testing. REASONING: Pseudocyesis is a somatic manifestation of strong psychological desire or conviction of pregnancy producing real physical signs; distinguishing it from very early or chemical pregnancy requires careful correlation of reliable negative hCG and imaging with psychosocial context to avoid incorrect reassurance or missed psychiatric care.

[Experience #7]
Pattern: Doctor concluded chemical pregnancy/early spontaneous abortion despite multiple high-quality negative objective tests (serial quantitative serum hCGs in the nonpregnant range and negative transvaginal ultrasound), and the patient's social history shows active and prolonged efforts to conceive (stopped OCPs 6 months ago, no prior pregnancies) and strong emotional response (happy to share news).
Suggestion: Avoid anchoring on 'chemical pregnancy' when serial objective testing consistently indicates nonpregnant status. ACTIONS: 1) Apply probabilistic reasoning: if quantitative hCGs are repeatedly below pregnancy threshold and are not rising, and TVUS shows no sac, the pretest probability for ongoing/ended pregnancy is low—expand differential to include pseudocyesis and lab error causes. 2) Ask targeted questions to rule out alternative explanations (recent hCG-containing medications, heterophile antibodies, prior home test details). 3) If uncertainty persists, seek confirmatory laboratory review (repeat serum hCG with a different assay or lab) before labeling as 'chemical pregnancy'. REASONING: Premature closure on an early pregnancy diagnosis may lead to inappropriate advice (e.g., expectant management for miscarriage) and miss psychiatric causes; confirmatory testing and broadened differential are necessary when objective data are repeatedly negative."}

Suggestion: When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes.

The patient is a nurse, increasing access to equipment and skills for intravenous manipulation. Despite hypotension and tachycardia, there is lack of corroborating signs of ongoing bleeding or hemolysis.
Suggestion: Perform a focused dermatologic and venous site exam: inspect for patterned scabs, linear tracks, healed puncture wounds, unexplained adhesive residues, or tubing marks. Document photographs (with consent) and compare bilateral arms. Ask explicit questions about IV access, self-injection of substances (including own blood), or use of sharps at home or work. Secure sharp instruments if immediate risk is identified. Rationale: visible puncture marks and crusting are direct physical clues of self-inflicted intravenous manipulation; documenting and addressing access can prevent further harm and provide objective evidence guiding psychiatric referral and safe management."}

ACTIONS: 1) Explicitly ask about timing/number/brands of home tests, prior positive results, and verify any prior outside lab hCG results. 2) Re-confirm serial serum quantitative hCG and review lab reports to exclude lab error or heterophile antibodies. 3) If testing reliably negative, perform focused psychosocial and psychiatric screening (ask about intense desire to conceive, recent pregnancy loss or infertility, mood symptoms, body image changes, and any secondary gains). 4) Arrange early mental health referral and schedule close follow-up to reassess symptoms and objective testing. REASONING: Pseudocyesis is a somatic manifestation of strong psychological desire or conviction of pregnancy producing real physical signs; distinguishing it from very early or chemical pregnancy requires careful correlation of reliable negative hCG and imaging with psychosocial context to avoid incorrect reassurance or missed psychiatric care."}, {"id": 7, "suggestion": "Avoid anchoring on 'chemical pregnancy' when serial objective testing consistently indicates nonpregnant status. REASONING: Premature closure on an early pregnancy diagnosis may lead to inappropriate advice (e.g., expectant management for miscarriage) and miss psychiatric causes; confirmatory testing and broadened differential are necessary when objective data are repeatedly negative."}], "reasoning": "Both experiences directly match the current clinical situation. Both experiences involve the discrepancy between subjective pregnancy symptoms and negative objective testing.", "context_for_doctor": "[Experience #6]
Pattern: Patient reports strong, repeated positive home urine pregnancy tests and classic early pregnancy symptoms (breast tenderness, nausea, urinary frequency, mild abdominal enlargement and weight gain), but objective testing is repeatedly negative: urine hCG negative, quantitative serum hCG nonpregnant on serial measurements, and transvaginal ultrasound shows no gestational sac.
Suggestion: When patients have persistent pregnancy symptoms and strong conviction of pregnancy but all objective pregnancy tests (urine and serial quantitative serum hCG) and TVUS are negative, include pseudocyesis on the differential. ACTIONS: 1) Explicitly ask about timing/number/brands of home tests, prior positive results, and verify any prior outside lab hCG results. 2) Re-confirm serial serum quantitative hCG and review lab reports to exclude lab error or heterophile antibodies. 3) If testing reliably negative, perform focused psychosocial and psychiatric screening (ask about intense desire to conceive, recent pregnancy loss or infertility, mood symptoms, body image changes, and any secondary gains). 4) Arrange early mental health referral and schedule close follow-up to reassess symptoms and objective testing. REASONING: Pseudocyesis is a somatic manifestation of strong psychological desire or conviction of pregnancy producing real physical signs; distinguishing it from very early or chemical pregnancy requires careful correlation of reliable negative hCG and imaging with psychosocial context to avoid incorrect reassurance or missed psychiatric care.

[Experience #7]
Pattern: Doctor concluded chemical pregnancy/early spontaneous abortion despite multiple high-quality negative objective tests (serial quantitative serum hCGs in the nonpregnant range and negative transvaginal ultrasound), and the patient's social history shows active and prolonged efforts to conceive (stopped OCPs 6 months ago, no prior pregnancies) and strong emotional response (happy to share news).
Suggestion: Avoid anchoring on 'chemical pregnancy' when serial objective testing consistently indicates nonpregnant status. ACTIONS: 1) Apply probabilistic reasoning: if quantitative hCGs are repeatedly below pregnancy threshold and are not rising, and TVUS shows no sac, the pretest probability for ongoing/ended pregnancy is low—expand differential to include pseudocyesis and lab error causes. 2) Ask targeted questions to rule out alternative explanations (recent hCG-containing medications, heterophile antibodies, prior home test details). 3) If uncertainty persists, seek confirmatory laboratory review (repeat serum hCG with a different assay or lab) before labeling as 'chemical pregnancy'. REASONING: Premature closure on an early pregnancy diagnosis may lead to inappropriate advice (e.g., expectant management for miscarriage) and miss psychiatric causes; confirmatory testing and broadened differential are necessary when objective data are repeatedly negative."}

ID: 10 | Observation: Pitting of the nails noted on exam and patient reports chronic dandruff (scalp scaling)  subtle cutaneous/nail findings that can be manifestations of psoriasis were present but not pursued.

{"status": "experiences_selected", "selected": [{"id": 1, "suggestion": "When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes."}, {"id": 2, "suggestion": "Recognize that a high reticulocyte count with absent biochemical/hematologic evidence of hemolysis and no identified bleeding source should prompt consideration of specimen contamination, specimen manipulation (exogenous transfusion, reinfusion), or factitious blood loss. Actions: request chain-of-custody for specimens, perform witnessed sample collection and immediate repeat testing (including point-of-care Hb) to exclude lab tampering; compare venous versus capillary/point-of-care samples. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics."}], "reasoning": "ID 1 directly matches the current case: 26-year-old nurse with severe anemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL), marked reticulocytosis (13.3%), crusts along veins on left arm, tachycardia and hypotension. The demographic, clinical findings, and lab values are identical.

ID 2 directly matches the specific lab pattern: normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers normal, raising concern for nonphysiologic causes. This exactly matches the current lab findings and the concern about factitious etiology.

Both experiences are medically directly relevant to the current clinical situation of unexplained anemia in a healthcare worker with access to phlebotomy equipment and crusts along veins.", "context_for_doctor": "[Experience #1]
Pattern: Patient is a 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anaemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL) and marked reticulocytosis (13.3%) despite exhaustive negative workup for bleeding, hemolysis, marrow disease, GI and gynecologic sources, and normal iron/B12/epu. Physical exam shows crusts along veins on the left arm and pale appearance; vitals show tachycardia and hypotension. The patient expresses high cancer concern and requests invasive diagnostic laparoscopy.
Suggestion: When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes.

[Experience #2]
Pattern: Lab pattern shows normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers (LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin), direct antiglobulin test, peripheral smear including specialized hematopathology review, flow cytometry for PNH, erythropoietin, and bone marrow biopsy are normal. Stool occult blood, EGD, abdominal CT, pelvic exam and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Repeated identical CBC results despite multiple draws raise concern for nonphysiologic causes.
Suggestion: Recognize that a high reticulocyte count with absent biochemical/hematologic evidence of hemolysis and no identified bleeding source should prompt consideration of specimen contamination, specimen manipulation (exogenous transfusion, reinfusion), or factitious blood loss. Actions: request chain-of-custody for specimens, perform witnessed sample collection and immediate repeat testing (including point-of-care Hb) to exclude lab tampering; compare venous versus capillary/point-of-care samples. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics."}

Suggestion: Before diagnosing reactive arthritis, seek objective evidence of inflammatory arthritis and infection. Specifically: (1) Carefully document and attempt to elicit objective synovitis (joint swelling, warmth, reduced passive ROM) and repeat exam during symptomatic flare; (2) consider bedside joint aspiration if true effusion suspected to demonstrate inflammatory fluid; (3) refrain from inferring post-infectious reactive arthritis when inflammatory markers, stool studies, joint imaging/ultrasound, and HLA-B27 are repeatedly negative. Despite hypotension and tachycardia, there is lack of corroborating signs of ongoing bleeding or hemolysis.
Suggestion: Perform a focused dermatologic and venous site exam: inspect for patterned scabs, linear tracks, healed puncture wounds, unexplained adhesive residues, or tubing marks. Document photographs (with consent) and compare bilateral arms. Ask explicit questions about IV access, self-injection of substances (including own blood), or use of sharps at home or work. Secure sharp instruments if immediate risk is identified. Rationale: visible puncture marks and crusting are direct physical clues of self-inflicted intravenous manipulation; documenting and addressing access can prevent further harm and provide objective evidence guiding psychiatric referral and safe management."}

Doctor: Dr. Agent: REQUEST TEST: Vital_Signs and REQUEST TEST: Abdominal_Examination. Dr. Agent: Please tell me your age, when the right arm pain and gastrointestinal symptoms began, and whether you've had similar episodes before.
Measurement: RESULTS: **Vital_Signs:** - Temperature: 37.0C (98.6F) - Blood_Pressure: 115/75 mmHg - Heart_Rate: 82 bpm - Respiratory_Rate: 18 breaths/min **Abdominal_Examination:** - Inspection: No visible abnormalities. - Auscultation: Normal bowel sounds. - Percussion: Diffuse tenderness, but no peritoneal signs. - Palpation: Diffuse abdominal tenderness in all four quadrants without rebound or guarding.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: How old are you, exactly when did the right arm and gastrointestinal symptoms begin, can you describe the arm pain (sharp/dull, constant or intermittent, any numbness/weakness or radiation), and what GI symptoms are you having (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bloody stools)?
Patient: I'm 21 years old. The right arm pain and my diarrhea and nausea all started around a week agono trauma or anything, it's a constant dull ache with limited range of motion, no numbness, weakness, or radiation. No vomiting or bloody stools, just the nausea and loose stools.
Doctor: Doctor: REQUEST TEST: Right_Arm_Examination. Have you had similar episodes before, any prior evaluations or diagnoses, chronic illnesses or medications, and any recent fever, urinary symptoms, or new sexual partners?
Measurement: RESULTS: **Musculoskeletal_Examination (Right_Arm):** - Inspection: No erythema or edema. - Palpation: Tenderness without specific localization. - Range_of_Motion: Limited due to pain.
Doctor: Have you had similar episodes before or prior evaluations/diagnoses, any chronic illnesses or regular medications, and any recent antibiotics, travel, or sick contacts?
Patient: I've had similar episodes multiple times in the past year, bringing me to the ER each time, but no clear diagnoses or treatments worked. No chronic illnesses, regular medications, recent antibiotics, travel, or sick contacts.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you ever had blood tests (CBC/CRP/ESR), stool studies, joint imaging/ultrasound, HLA-B27 testing, or joint aspiration for these episodesif so, what were the resultsand do you have any history of depression/anxiety, sleep problems, substance use, or loss of work/function because of these symptoms?
Patient: They've done blood tests like CBC and CRP before, but everything was normalno elevations or anything diagnostic. No stool studies, joint imaging was unremarkable, and no HLA-B27 or aspirations were done. No depression, anxiety, sleep issues, substance use, or major loss of work, though these episodes are disruptive.
Doctor: Do your GI and arm symptoms always occur together and how long does each episode usually last; are there any identifiable triggers or recent stressors, and do you have sleep disturbance, excessive worry about your health, or any impact on work or relationships from these episodes?
Patient: Yeah, the GI symptoms like diarrhea and nausea always hit at the same time as the arm pain in these episodes, and each one usually lasts about a week or so before easing up a bit. No obvious triggers or recent stressors that I can think of, and while I don't have sleep issues or worry excessively about my health, these flare-ups have messed with my work and intimacy with my partnerlike pain during sex.
Doctor: Do you ever get eye redness, pain, or discharge during these episodes, and have you had urethral symptoms (dysuria or discharge) or a recent new sexual partner or known STI? REQUEST TEST: CBC_CRP_ESR and REQUEST TEST: Stool_Studies and REQUEST TEST: Right_Arm_Ultrasound.
Measurement: RESULTS: **Complete_Blood_Count (CBC):** - WBC: Normal - Hemoglobin: Normal - Platelets: Normal **Inflammatory_Markers (CRP & ESR):** - CRP: Normal - ESR: Normal **Stool_Studies:** - Fecal_Occult_Blood_Test: Negative **Right_Arm_Ultrasound:** NORMAL READINGS
Doctor: Do you ever get eye redness, pain, discharge, or any urethral symptoms (dysuria/discharge) or skin rashes/sores during these episodes, and have you had any known STIs or recent new sexual partners? Have you experienced low mood, anxiety, sleep disturbance, excessive worry about your health, or noticed that symptoms sometimes help you avoid work/obligations or gain attentionwould you be willing to complete a brief PHQ-9/GAD-7 screen?
Patient: No, I haven't had any eye redness, pain, discharge, urethral symptoms like burning or discharge, or skin rashes/sores during these episodes, and no known STIsI've only been with my one steady partner. No low mood, anxiety, sleep issues, or excessive health worries, and the symptoms don't help me avoid work or get attentionthey just disrupt things. Sure, I'd be willing to do a PHQ-9 or GAD-7 screen.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: REQUEST TEST: PHQ9_GAD7; what treatments (NSAIDs, opioids, antibiotics, physical therapy, or others) have you tried in past episodes and did anything provide relief?
Measurement: RESULTS: **PHQ9_GAD7:** NORMAL READINGS

ID: 3 | Observation: Patient repeatedly requests invasive gynecologic procedures (diagnostic laparoscopy) and expresses intense fear of cancer despite extensive negative imaging and testing; psychiatric symptoms include depressed mood and high health anxiety. The clinical course (persistent symptoms despite leave from work) and request for procedures may represent secondary gain for attention or fulfillment of sick role.
ID: 8 | Observation: No documented targeted psychiatric or psychosocial assessment was done to explore the patient's emotional state, fertility-related stressors, or potential somatoform manifestations despite classic psychosomatic symptoms and strong conviction of pregnancy.
ID: 16 | Observation: The agent relied on temporal association (diarrhea and joint pain starting together) without confirming typical reactive arthritis features: asymmetric lower-extremity oligoarthritis, enthesitis, conjunctivitis/urethritis, or antecedent known enteric infection; also patient denied classic extra-articular signs and had no response trial to NSAIDs.

ID: 12 | Observation: Negative rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP but elevated ESR/CRP  seronegative inflammatory arthritis is supported; absence of erosive change on X-ray and presence of subchondral sclerosis/joint space narrowing can coexist with psoriatic arthropathy, especially early disease.
ID: 14 | Observation: Recurrent brief diarrheal episodes (a few days), migratory asymmetric joint pain focused on one arm, no objective inflammatory signsnormal WBC, CRP, ESR, normal stool studies, no joint swelling or warmth on exam or imaging, negative HLA-B27, and symptoms persisted across multiple ER visits without progressive structural findings.
ID: 5 | Observation: Extensive invasive testing (EGD, CT abdomen/pelvis, bone marrow biopsy, transvaginal ultrasound, planned hysteroscopy/colonoscopy) was pursued despite multiple red flags for nonorganic disease and normal directed tests. This led to recommendations for further invasive gynecologic and endoscopic procedures without addressing potential factitious etiologies.
ID: 2 | Observation: Lab pattern shows normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers (LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin), direct antiglobulin test, peripheral smear including specialized hematopathology review, flow cytometry for PNH, erythropoietin, and bone marrow biopsy are normal. ID: 7 | Observation: Doctor concluded chemical pregnancy/early spontaneous abortion despite multiple high-quality negative objective tests (serial quantitative serum hCGs in the nonpregnant range and negative transvaginal ultrasound), and the patient's social history shows active and prolonged efforts to conceive (stopped OCPs 6 months ago, no prior pregnancies) and strong emotional response (happy to share news).
ID: 13 | Observation: Back pain with limited spinal mobility reported, though not classical inflammatory pattern; coexistence of axial symptoms in an older patient with peripheral oligoarthritis should raise suspicion for seronegative spondyloarthropathy variants.
ID: 1 | Observation: Patient is a 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anaemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL) and marked reticulocytosis (13.3%) despite exhaustive negative workup for bleeding, hemolysis, marrow disease, GI and gynecologic sources, and normal iron/B12/epu. Physical exam shows crusts along veins on the left arm and pale appearance; vitals show tachycardia and hypotension. The patient expresses high cancer concern and requests invasive diagnostic laparoscopy.

Pattern: Recurrent brief diarrheal episodes (a few days), migratory asymmetric joint pain focused on one arm, no objective inflammatory signs—normal WBC, CRP, ESR, normal stool studies, no joint swelling or warmth on exam or imaging, negative HLA-B27, and symptoms persisted across multiple ER visits without progressive structural findings.
Suggestion: Before diagnosing reactive arthritis, seek objective evidence of inflammatory arthritis and infection. Specifically: (1) Carefully document and attempt to elicit objective synovitis (joint swelling, warmth, reduced passive ROM) and repeat exam during symptomatic flare; (2) consider bedside joint aspiration if true effusion suspected to demonstrate inflammatory fluid; (3) refrain from inferring post-infectious reactive arthritis when inflammatory markers, stool studies, joint imaging/ultrasound, and HLA-B27 are repeatedly negative. Rationale: Reactive arthritis is an inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy typically with objective synovitis, enthesitis, or extra-articular features; without objective evidence its probability is low and alternative (functional/somatization) causes become more likely.

Use validated brief screens (PHQ-9, GAD-7) and ask about symptom impact on work/relationships. If positive or if symptoms are inconsistent with objective findings, refer early to mental health or psychosomatic medicine and consider multidisciplinary care (physiotherapy, pain clinic, CBT). Rationale: Recurrent multisystem symptoms with normal tests raise somatization which responds to structured psychological interventions; early recognition reduces unnecessary testing and harms."}

Rationale: Reactive arthritis is an inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy typically with objective synovitis, enthesitis, or extra-articular features; without objective evidence its probability is low and alternative (functional/somatization) causes become more likely."}], "reasoning": "Both experiences directly match the current clinical situation. Pattern: Symptoms lack focal/localizing features and often coincide with healthcare-seeking behavior: diffuse abdominal tenderness without peritoneal signs, arm tenderness nonlocalized, normal imaging/ultrasound/ labs across episodes, and the patient has multiple prior ER visits for similar complaints.
Suggestion: Actively screen for somatoform/somatization and psychiatric comorbidity: ask about mood/anxiety symptoms, sleep, functional impairment, stressors, secondary gains, and prior mental health diagnoses or treatments. Use validated brief screens (PHQ-9, GAD-7) and ask about symptom impact on work/relationships. If positive or if symptoms are inconsistent with objective findings, refer early to mental health or psychosomatic medicine and consider multidisciplinary care (physiotherapy, pain clinic, CBT). Rationale: Recurrent multisystem symptoms with normal tests raise somatization which responds to structured psychological interventions; early recognition reduces unnecessary testing and harms.

[Experience #14]
Pattern: Recurrent brief diarrheal episodes (a few days), migratory asymmetric joint pain focused on one arm, no objective inflammatory signs—normal WBC, CRP, ESR, normal stool studies, no joint swelling or warmth on exam or imaging, negative HLA-B27, and symptoms persisted across multiple ER visits without progressive structural findings.
Suggestion: Before diagnosing reactive arthritis, seek objective evidence of inflammatory arthritis and infection. Specifically: (1) Carefully document and attempt to elicit objective synovitis (joint swelling, warmth, reduced passive ROM) and repeat exam during symptomatic flare; (2) consider bedside joint aspiration if true effusion suspected to demonstrate inflammatory fluid; (3) refrain from inferring post-infectious reactive arthritis when inflammatory markers, stool studies, joint imaging/ultrasound, and HLA-B27 are repeatedly negative. Rationale: Reactive arthritis is an inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy typically with objective synovitis, enthesitis, or extra-articular features; without objective evidence its probability is low and alternative (functional/somatization) causes become more likely."}

Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes."}, {"id": 2, "suggestion": "Recognize that a high reticulocyte count with absent biochemical/hematologic evidence of hemolysis and no identified bleeding source should prompt consideration of specimen contamination, specimen manipulation (exogenous transfusion, reinfusion), or factitious blood loss. Actions: request chain-of-custody for specimens, perform witnessed sample collection and immediate repeat testing (including point-of-care Hb) to exclude lab tampering; compare venous versus capillary/point-of-care samples. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics."}], "reasoning": "ID 1 directly matches the current case: 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL), marked reticulocytosis (13.3%), crusts along veins on left arm, tachycardia/hypotension, extensive negative workup, and cancer concern. ID 2 directly matches the lab pattern: normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers and other tests are normal, with repeated identical CBC results raising concern for nonphysiologic causes. Both experiences closely mirror the current clinical presentation.", "context_for_doctor": "[Experience #1]
Pattern: Patient is a 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anaemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL) and marked reticulocytosis (13.3%) despite exhaustive negative workup for bleeding, hemolysis, marrow disease, GI and gynecologic sources, and normal iron/B12/epu. Physical exam shows crusts along veins on the left arm and pale appearance; vitals show tachycardia and hypotension. The patient expresses high cancer concern and requests invasive diagnostic laparoscopy.
Suggestion: When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes.

[Experience #2]
Pattern: Lab pattern shows normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers (LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin), direct antiglobulin test, peripheral smear including specialized hematopathology review, flow cytometry for PNH, erythropoietin, and bone marrow biopsy are normal. Stool occult blood, EGD, abdominal CT, pelvic exam and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Repeated identical CBC results despite multiple draws raise concern for nonphysiologic causes.
Suggestion: Recognize that a high reticulocyte count with absent biochemical/hematologic evidence of hemolysis and no identified bleeding source should prompt consideration of specimen contamination, specimen manipulation (exogenous transfusion, reinfusion), or factitious blood loss. Actions: request chain-of-custody for specimens, perform witnessed sample collection and immediate repeat testing (including point-of-care Hb) to exclude lab tampering; compare venous versus capillary/point-of-care samples. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics."}

Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes."}, {"id": 2, "suggestion": "Recognize that a high reticulocyte count with absent biochemical/hematologic evidence of hemolysis and no identified bleeding source should prompt consideration of specimen contamination, specimen manipulation (exogenous transfusion, reinfusion), or factitious blood loss. Actions: request chain-of-custody for specimens, perform witnessed sample collection and immediate repeat testing (including point-of-care Hb) to exclude lab tampering; compare venous versus capillary/point-of-care samples. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics."}], "reasoning": "ID 1 directly matches the current clinical situation: 26-year-old nurse with severe anemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL), marked reticulocytosis (13.3%), exhaustive negative workup for bleeding/hemolysis, crusts along veins on left arm, tachycardia/hypotension, high cancer concern, and request for invasive procedures. ID 2 directly matches the lab pattern: normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) despite normal hemolysis markers, repeated identical CBC results raising concern for nonphysiologic causes. Both experiences closely mirror the current patient's presentation of unexplained anemia with reticulocytosis in a healthcare worker with access to equipment.", "context_for_doctor": "[Experience #1]
Pattern: Patient is a 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anaemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL) and marked reticulocytosis (13.3%) despite exhaustive negative workup for bleeding, hemolysis, marrow disease, GI and gynecologic sources, and normal iron/B12/epu. Physical exam shows crusts along veins on the left arm and pale appearance; vitals show tachycardia and hypotension. The patient expresses high cancer concern and requests invasive diagnostic laparoscopy.
Suggestion: When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes.

[Experience #2]
Pattern: Lab pattern shows normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers (LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin), direct antiglobulin test, peripheral smear including specialized hematopathology review, flow cytometry for PNH, erythropoietin, and bone marrow biopsy are normal. Stool occult blood, EGD, abdominal CT, pelvic exam and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Repeated identical CBC results despite multiple draws raise concern for nonphysiologic causes.
Suggestion: Recognize that a high reticulocyte count with absent biochemical/hematologic evidence of hemolysis and no identified bleeding source should prompt consideration of specimen contamination, specimen manipulation (exogenous transfusion, reinfusion), or factitious blood loss. Actions: request chain-of-custody for specimens, perform witnessed sample collection and immediate repeat testing (including point-of-care Hb) to exclude lab tampering; compare venous versus capillary/point-of-care samples. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics."}

Pattern: Patient is a 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anaemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL) and marked reticulocytosis (13.3%) despite exhaustive negative workup for bleeding, hemolysis, marrow disease, GI and gynecologic sources, and normal iron/B12/epu. Suggestion: When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes.

[Experience #2]
Pattern: Lab pattern shows normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers (LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin), direct antiglobulin test, peripheral smear including specialized hematopathology review, flow cytometry for PNH, erythropoietin, and bone marrow biopsy are normal. Stool occult blood, EGD, abdominal CT, pelvic exam and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Repeated identical CBC results despite multiple draws raise concern for nonphysiologic causes.
Suggestion: Recognize that a high reticulocyte count with absent biochemical/hematologic evidence of hemolysis and no identified bleeding source should prompt consideration of specimen contamination, specimen manipulation (exogenous transfusion, reinfusion), or factitious blood loss. Actions: request chain-of-custody for specimens, perform witnessed sample collection and immediate repeat testing (including point-of-care Hb) to exclude lab tampering; compare venous versus capillary/point-of-care samples. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics."}

ID: 2 | Observation: Lab pattern shows normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers (LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin), direct antiglobulin test, peripheral smear including specialized hematopathology review, flow cytometry for PNH, erythropoietin, and bone marrow biopsy are normal. Stool occult blood, EGD, abdominal CT, pelvic exam and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Repeated identical CBC results despite multiple draws raise concern for nonphysiologic causes.
ID: 4 | Observation: Physical findings include crusts along veins on left armlocal lesions consistent with repeated venipuncture, IV access, or self-inflicted injury. The patient is a nurse, increasing access to equipment and skills for intravenous manipulation. Despite hypotension and tachycardia, there is lack of corroborating signs of ongoing bleeding or hemolysis.
ID: 17 | Observation: Limited therapeutic probing was donepatient never tried NSAIDs and there was no trial of symptom-directed therapy or functional assessments to distinguish inflammatory vs noninflammatory pain. Also, physical exam lacked tests for non-organic signs (e.g., Hoover sign, Waddell's signs) or functional pain reproduction.
ID: 14 | Observation: Recurrent brief diarrheal episodes (a few days), migratory asymmetric joint pain focused on one arm, no objective inflammatory signsnormal WBC, CRP, ESR, normal stool studies, no joint swelling or warmth on exam or imaging, negative HLA-B27, and symptoms persisted across multiple ER visits without progressive structural findings.
ID: 7 | Observation: Doctor concluded chemical pregnancy/early spontaneous abortion despite multiple high-quality negative objective tests (serial quantitative serum hCGs in the nonpregnant range and negative transvaginal ultrasound), and the patient's social history shows active and prolonged efforts to conceive (stopped OCPs 6 months ago, no prior pregnancies) and strong emotional response (happy to share news).
ID: 11 | Observation: Presentation of asymmetric mono/oligoarticular knee involvement with prior brief episode in the contralateral knee, acute swelling with warmth and tenderness, and raised inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP)  pattern is more typical of inflammatory arthritis rather than purely mechanical OA.
ID: 15 | Observation: Symptoms lack focal/localizing features and often coincide with healthcare-seeking behavior: diffuse abdominal tenderness without peritoneal signs, arm tenderness nonlocalized, normal imaging/ultrasound/ labs across episodes, and the patient has multiple prior ER visits for similar complaints.
ID: 5 | Observation: Extensive invasive testing (EGD, CT abdomen/pelvis, bone marrow biopsy, transvaginal ultrasound, planned hysteroscopy/colonoscopy) was pursued despite multiple red flags for nonorganic disease and normal directed tests. This led to recommendations for further invasive gynecologic and endoscopic procedures without addressing potential factitious etiologies.
ID: 16 | Observation: The agent relied on temporal association (diarrhea and joint pain starting together) without confirming typical reactive arthritis features: asymmetric lower-extremity oligoarthritis, enthesitis, conjunctivitis/urethritis, or antecedent known enteric infection; also patient denied classic extra-articular signs and had no response trial to NSAIDs.
ID: 6 | Observation: Patient reports strong, repeated positive home urine pregnancy tests and classic early pregnancy symptoms (breast tenderness, nausea, urinary frequency, mild abdominal enlargement and weight gain), but objective testing is repeatedly negative: urine hCG negative, quantitative serum hCG nonpregnant on serial measurements, and transvaginal ultrasound shows no gestational sac.
ID: 1 | Observation: Patient is a 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anaemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL) and marked reticulocytosis (13.3%) despite exhaustive negative workup for bleeding, hemolysis, marrow disease, GI and gynecologic sources, and normal iron/B12/epu. Physical exam shows crusts along veins on the left arm and pale appearance; vitals show tachycardia and hypotension. The patient expresses high cancer concern and requests invasive diagnostic laparoscopy.
ID: 12 | Observation: Negative rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP but elevated ESR/CRP  seronegative inflammatory arthritis is supported; absence of erosive change on X-ray and presence of subchondral sclerosis/joint space narrowing can coexist with psoriatic arthropathy, especially early disease.
ID: 8 | Observation: No documented targeted psychiatric or psychosocial assessment was done to explore the patient's emotional state, fertility-related stressors, or potential somatoform manifestations despite classic psychosomatic symptoms and strong conviction of pregnancy.

final_response: {"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_15", "summary": "Key teaching points: 1) Do not exclude hemophilia A based on a single normal one-stage FVIII assay or standard gene sequencing; use chromogenic assays and inversion/MLPA testing when clinical suspicion persists. 2) Thorough targeted family history and testing of affected relatives can reveal diagnoses missed in the proband. 3) Reconcile discordant lab results (prolonged ACT with normal panels) with repeat testing, mixing studies, and early orthopedic aspiration when hemarthrosis is present.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

{"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_1", "summary": "Three key learning points saved: 1) When SPEP and downstream tests disagree, repeat and use more specific assays (reference immunofixation, free light chains, peripheral smear, cryocrit). 2) Evaluate and act on clinical hyperviscosity despite normal serum viscosity; obtain cryocrit and consider plasmapheresis when vision threatened. 3) For suspected Waldenstrom, pursue targeted marrow studies (flow cytometry, MYD88) as marrow involvement can be patchy and standard biopsy may be nondiagnostic.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

### 1. Doctor's Initial Information
{
  "objective": "Evaluate and diagnose the dermatological condition presented by the patient, focusing on lesions with potential oncologic implications.",
  "patient_demographics": "62-year-old male",
  "chief_complaint": "The patient has recently immigrated to the US from Africa and seeks evaluation for a non-healing, red, crusty lesion on the shaft of his penis and a similar lesion on his left middle finger. Previous treatments in his home country for syphilis and eczema have been unsuccessful. The patient is a smoker, with a history of two packs per day for the last 30 years.",
  "primary_symptom": "Non-healing, crusty, red lesions on the penile shaft and left middle finger",
  "secondary_symptoms": [
    "Lesions are painless",
    "History of unsuccessful treatment for syphilis and eczema"
  ]
}

### 2. Dialogue Trajectory
[Turn 0] Doctor: Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Agent; I'll begin by checking your vital signs and performing an abdominal examination. REQUEST TEST: Vital_Signs REQUEST TEST: Abdominal_Examination

They've stayed about the same size, no bleeding or itching, and they're completely painless. I tried treatments for syphilis and eczema there, but nothing worked.
[Turn 4] Doctor: Doctor: Have you had unprotected sex or multiple sexual partners, any history of genital warts/HPV, and are you circumcised?

final_response: {"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_13", "summary": "Three key learning points: (1) Do not rely on superficial punch biopsies to distinguish in situ disease from invasive SCC\u2014obtain excisional/deeper biopsy and explicit pathology comment about invasion. (2) Avoid premature full systemic staging and radical surgical recommendations until invasion is confirmed; tailor imaging and referral to histologic risk. (3) Interpret multiple similar cutaneous lesions cautiously\u2014metastasis to distant skin is unlikely; consider synchronous multifocal Bowen's disease or autoinoculation and use clinical history, dermatopathology correlation, and targeted testing to guide management.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

final_response: {"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_13", "summary": "The doctor correctly identified malignant squamous cell features but misdiagnosed invasive squamous cell carcinoma instead of Bowen's Disease (squamous cell carcinoma in situ). Three key learning points: 1) Need to specifically assess for basement membrane invasion to distinguish in situ vs invasive carcinoma, 2) Clinical-pathological correlation showing indolent course with multiple lesions favors field cancerization of in situ disease over metastatic spread, and 3) Bowen's Disease should be included in differential for chronic crusty plaques in elderly smokers with appropriate risk factors. The doctor performed extensive testing but missed the critical histopathological distinction and clinical correlation.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

{"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_16", "summary": "The doctor incorrectly diagnosed vestibular neuritis instead of labyrinthitis due to three key reasoning errors: 1) Failure to adequately investigate conflicting hearing test results, 2) Over-reliance on normal MRI while under-valuing clinical hearing findings, and 3) Inefficient test ordering that didn't resolve the core diagnostic uncertainty about hearing status. The critical learning is that acute vertigo with hearing loss following viral illness should strongly suggest labyrinthitis, and hearing assessment should be prioritized and carefully verified when test results conflict.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

final_response: {"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_15", "summary": "The doctor missed Hemophilia A diagnosis due to three critical errors: 1) Misinterpreting prolonged ACT with normal PT as insignificant when it specifically indicates intrinsic pathway defect, 2) Over-relying on normal factor assays in an infant despite strong clinical evidence, and 3) Failing to recognize the diagnostic pattern of X-linked inheritance (affected maternal uncle + affected male child). The doctor ordered excessive testing while dismissing the classic presentation of spontaneous hemarthrosis with positive family history and abnormal coagulation screening test.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

{"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_1", "summary": "The doctor correctly identified monoclonal gammopathy but failed to reach the specific diagnosis of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. Key learning points: 1) When monoclonal gammopathy (especially pentameric/IgM) is found in an older patient with visual symptoms, Waldenstrom should be high on differential; 2) Normal initial tests don't rule out Waldenstrom - need specialized hematology evaluation; 3) Bilateral retinal vein occlusions in older patients should prompt early consideration of hyperviscosity syndromes from hematologic malignancies. The doctor's main error was stopping at \"monoclonal gammopathy causing retinal issues\" without pursuing the specific underlying malignancy.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

final_response: {"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_13", "summary": "Three critical learning points: 1) Do not infer invasion from histologic descriptors alone\u2014request explicit pathologist statement on dermal invasion/depth or obtain deeper/excisional biopsy/dermatopathology consult. 2) Consider multicentric Bowen's disease/erythroplasia of Queyrat in painless crusted penile lesions with similar lesions elsewhere and negative systemic workup\u2014manage as in-situ disease unless invasion proven. 3) Avoid premature oncologic staging/surgical referral and imaging until invasion is confirmed; tailor further workup and treatment based on invasion status and risk features.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

{"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_16", "summary": "Three critical learning points saved: 1) Clarify and act on acute new hearing loss concurrent with vertigo\u2014supports labyrinthitis over vestibular neuritis. 2) Reconcile conflicting bedside and formal auditory tests\u2014repeat testing/ENT consult if discrepancy. 3) Integrate bedside vestibular signs and cochlear symptoms rather than over-relying on MRI/head-impulse alone when distinguishing peripheral causes.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}
